importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news report's update, indicating when the public was informed about the NTSB's preliminary findings regarding the crash of Brett James' plane.
The year when Brett James co-wrote 'Jesus, Take the Wheel' for Carrie Underwood's debut album, marking a pivotal moment in his career and a major milestone in country music history.
The date of the fatal plane crash, which is central to the incident and the investigation by the NTSB.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from the crash on September 18 to the release of the preliminary NTSB report on October 20, highlighting the timeline of investigation and public disclosure.

keyTakeAways: Brett James, a Grammy-winning songwriter, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, along with two others, after his plane entered a 'tightening spiral' during a planned visual approach to runway 7.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) found no mechanical issues with the Cirrus SR22T aircraft involved.

James had requested a visual approach to runway 7, which was approved, but failed to change his radio frequency to the common traffic advisory frequency, leading to a loss of communication with air traffic control.
The controller attempted to communicate that James had not changed his frequency, but there were no further transmissions from James.
The plane flew over the runway and initiated a left turn and descent, culminating in the spiral and crash.
James was a prominent songwriter in country music, having collaborated with major artists such as Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, and co-wrote the song 'Out Last Night'.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He was the pilot and one of the victims of the fatal plane crash, making him central to the incident and investigation.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The U.S. federal agency responsible for investigating transportation accidents.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The NTSB conducted and released a preliminary report on the crash, providing official findings on the cause and circumstances of the accident.

namedEntities.name: Cirrus SR22T
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The specific type of plane involved in the crash, which was examined by NTSB investigators and found to have no mechanical problems.

namedEntities.name: Carrie Underwood
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country music singer and 'American Idol' champion.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: James co-wrote her breakout song 'Jesus, Take the Wheel' in 2005, which helped launch her career and established James as a top songwriter in the industry.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: James had a successful songwriting collaboration with Swift, highlighting his influence and prominence in the music industry.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A prominent country music artist and songwriter.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: James worked closely with Urban, reinforcing his reputation as a top-tier collaborator in country music.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A radio frequency used by pilots to report their position when no air traffic control is present.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Grammy-winning songwriter Brett James, known for his collaborations with major artists like Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, and Kenny Chesney, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, along with two others. The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) found no mechanical faults in the Cirrus SR22T aircraft involved. The incident occurred when James attempted a visual approach to runway 7 in Franklin, North Carolina, but failed to change to the common traffic advisory frequency (CTAF), resulting in a loss of communication with air traffic control. The plane then entered a tightening spiral and crashed. James’s career was defined by influential songs like 'Jesus, Take the Wheel' (with Carrie Underwood) and 'Out Last Night' (with Kenny Chesney), cementing his status as one of country music’s most sought-after songwriters.
title: Brett James’ Plane Crashes in North Carolina After Communication Failure, NTSB Reports
